questions.question:
Question 1: A patient diagnosed with ventricular tachycardia was started on a class1B anti-arrhythmic 
drug. Identify the drug.
questions.explanation: Mexiletine is a class 1B antiarrhythmic drug. It is a lidocaine analog.

questions.question:
Question 2: The additional mechanism by which class 1A drugs additionally prolong action potential 
duration is:
questions.explanation: Class IA antiarrhythmics block K+ channels leading to prolongation of action potential duration. The main action of class IA antiarrhythmics is blocking Na + channels causing: • Slowing the upstroke of the action potential • Slowing conduction • Prolonging the QRS duration

questions.question:
Question 3: Which of the following antiarrhythmics has the fastest rate of recovery on Na+ channel 
blockade?
questions.explanation:
Phenytoin and mexiletine which are class IB antiarrhythmic drugs have the fastest rate of 
recovery on Na+ channel blockade. They show the fastest dissociation kinetics to Na+ channel blockade (<1 sec). 224

questions.question: Question 4: Dofetilide belongs to which class of anti-arrhythmic drugs?
questions.explanation: Dofetilide belongs to class III of anti-arrhythmic drugs.

questions.question:
Question 5: An athlete diagnosed with atrial fibrillation was administered an antiarrhythmic drug. Several 
hours later, he complains of lower abdominal pain and not having passed urine since 
admission. Examination reveals a palpable bladder. Which was the most probable drug 
administered?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of urinary retention. Disopyramide, a class 1A antiarrhythmic is 
the drug most likely to cause these symptoms in this patient. It causes prominent anticholinergic side effects like urinary retention, dry mouth, blurred vision, 
precipitation of glaucoma, and constipation. It is the drug of choice for vagally mediated atrial fibrillation such as sleep-induced or atrial 
fibrillation in athletes.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following drugs is associated with QT prolongation?
questions.explanation:
QT prolongation is seen with quinidine. 225 
Sold by @itachibot It causes torsades de pointes, a life-threatening form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient presents with sinus bradycardia and bronchospasm. She was previously diagnosed 
with AV nodal reentrant tachycardia and had been started on an antiarrhythmic drug. Which 
of the following drugs is most likely being used?
questions.explanation:
Propafenone is the most likely drug being used in this patient as sinus bradycardia and 
bronchospasm are adverse effects seen with the use of this drug. These side effects are due to its weak beta-blocking activity.

questions.question:
Question 8: 217 
Sold by @itachibot Blurred vision in a patient being treated for paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia is most 
likely due to:
questions.explanation:
Blurred vision is the most common dose-related non-cardiac adverse effect of flecainide therapy. Flecainide is a class 1C antiarrhythmic agent. It acts mainly by sodium channel blockade. It does 
not cause any change in the action potential duration. Flecainide is used in paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVTs): • Atrioventricular nodal re-entrant tachycardia (AVNRT) • AV re-entrant tachycardia (AVRT) • Atrial fibrillation/atrial flutter (without structural heart disease)

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following antiarrhythmics has both class II and class III action?
questions.explanation:
Sotalol is a class III antiarrhythmic agent with additional beta-adrenergic blocking effects. (class II 
antiarrhythmic action) 226 
Sold by @itachibot Propranolol is a class II antiarrhythmic agent that has an additional Na+ channel blocking effect. 
(class I antiarrhythmic action) Esmolol is a short-acting beta-blocker with minimal/no action on cardiac Na+ and K+ channels.

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient presented to the ER with dizziness and palpitations. ECG is shown below. Which of 
the following drugs cannot be used in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The scenario and ECG findings (absent P waves and RR intervals that are irregularly irregular) are 
suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Lignocaine is not used in atrial arrhythmias. Lignocaine is a class 1B anti-arrhythmic agent. It blocks Na+ channels mostly in the 
closed/inactivated state. It is not used in atrial arrhythmias because the atrial action potential is so 
short that the Na+ channels are in a closed/ inactivated state for only a brief amount of time. Lignocaine is used in the acute treatment of ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation. Drugs mostly used for supraventricular arrhythmia are: • Adenosine • Verapamil • Diltiazem • Digoxin Drugs used for ventricular arrhythmia are: • Lidocaine • Mexiletine Drugs used in both conditions are: • Amiodarone • Beta-blockers • Class 1a / 1c antiarrhythmics

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following is incorrect regarding lignocaine?

options.c: In heart failure patients, both loading and maintenance doses are decreased
options.d: Indicated for prophylaxis of arryhythmias in all cases of suspected MI

questions.explanation:
Lignocaine decreases the incidence of arrhythmias in patients with suspected MI. However, 
it increases mortality probably by precipitating heart block or congestive heart failure. Hence it is 
not routinely used for prophylaxis in MI patients but it is used only when indicated. Gastrointestinal absorption of lignocaine is good but bioavailability is very less due to high 
first-pass hepatic metabolism. Therefore, it is not used through the oral route. Lignocaine has a high volume of distribution. The loading dose is required to achieve rapid 
action. In heart failure, both volumes of distribution and clearance are reduced. Both the loading dose 
and maintenance dose have to be reduced. 227 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is a correct statement regarding antiarrhythmics?

options.a: Sotalol has additional class II action
options.b: Esmolol has additional class IV action
options.c: Propranolol has additional class I action

questions.explanation:
Sotalol has both class II (beta-blocker) and class III action (K+ channel blockade). Though it is a 
nonselective beta-blocker, as an antiarrhythmic, it is classified under class III. Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker with additional membrane-stabilizing action especially 
at higher doses: Na+ channel blockade/ class I action. Esmolol is a beta 1 selective blocker that does not have any additional class effect.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 60-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of bluish discoloration of the skin on 
the sun-exposed areas. He has been on medication for monomorphic ventricular tachycardia 
for the past 3 years. Which drug is most likely implicated in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The scenario is suggestive of blue man syndrome which is most likely caused by amiodarone. One of the side effects of amiodarone is photosensitivity. In some cases, bluish discoloration of 
the skin is seen, predominantly in the sun-exposed areas. This could be due to the immune 
response in dermal layers by amiodarone or the accumulation of amiodarone in superficial layers 
of skin. The symptoms are reversible on drug discontinuation. The syndrome is related to both dose and 
photosensitivity. The side effects of amiodarone include: • Pulmonary fibrosis • Hypotension, depressed ventricular function • Torsades de pointes • Corneal microdeposits • Hepatotoxicity • Neuropathies • Photosensitivity • Thyroid dysfunction Other such syndromes associated with drugs are: • Red man syndrome - Vancomycin • Gray baby syndrome - Chloramphenicol

questions.question:
Question 14: Chronic usage of an antiarrhythmic drug leads to optic neuritis and smurf skin or 
ceruloderma in a patient. Which of the following is not a mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.explanation:
Optic neuritis and smurf skin (blueman syndrome or ceruloderma) are caused by 
amiodarone. It acts by blocking K+, Na+, and Ca2+ channels. It also blocks adrenergic effects. It 
does not block Cl- channels. 228 
Sold by @itachibot Amiodarone is classified as a class III antiarrhythmic agent. It exerts its function through the 
following mechanisms: • Blockade of transient outward delayed rectifier and inward rectifier K+ currents • Blockade of inactivated Na+ channels with a rapid rate of recovery • Decreases Ca2+ current • Non-competitive adrenergic blockade It is the drug of choice for acute treatment of VT and VF. The side effects of amiodarone include: • Pulmonary fibrosis • Hypotension, depressed ventricular function • Torsades de pointes • Corneal microdeposits • Hepatotoxicity • Neuropathies • Photosensitivity • Thyroid dysfunction

questions.question:
Question 15: Which of the following adverse effects is least likely in a patient who is on chronic 
amiodarone therapy?
questions.explanation:
Nephrotoxicity is not an adverse effect of chronic amiodarone therapy. Pulmonary 
fibrosis associated with dry cough is the most serious side effect of chronic amiodarone therapy. It 
can rapidly progress and become fatal. The side effects of amiodarone include: • Pulmonary fibrosis • Hypotension, depressed ventricular function • Torsades de pointes • Corneal microdeposits • Hepatotoxicity • Neuropathies • Photosensitivity • Thyroid dysfunction

questions.question:
Question 16: Which of the following antiarrhythmic drugs is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial 
lung disease?
questions.explanation:
Amiodarone is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease. 229 
Sold by @itachibot The most serious adverse effect during chronic amiodarone therapy is pulmonary fibrosis, which 
can be rapidly progressive and fatal. Underlying lung disease, doses of 400 mg/day or more, and 
recent pulmonary insults such as pneumonia appear to be risk factors for this condition. Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic drug. The side effects of amiodarone include: • Pulmonary fibrosis • Hypotension, depressed ventricular function • Torsades de pointes • Corneal microdeposits • Hepatotoxicity • Neuropathies • Photosensitivity • Thyroid dysfunction

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following statements about dronedarone is incorrect?

options.a: It does not contain iodine moiety
options.b: Has stronger antiadrenergic effects than amiodarone
options.c: Less effective antiarrhythmic when compared to amiodarone
options.d: Dose adjustment has to be done in renal failure

questions.explanation:
Dronedarone undergoes hepatic metabolism and hence dose adjustment is not required in renal 
failure as it is not excreted through the kidneys. Dronedarone is a non-iodinated congener of amiodarone. Like amiodarone, it is a blocker of 
multiple ion channels. It has stronger antiadrenergic effects than amiodarone. It is less effective in 
maintaining sinus rhythm and is considered less antiarrhythmic when compared to amiodarone. Unlike amiodarone, it does not cause thyroid dysfunction or pulmonary fibrosis. However, it 
causes hepatotoxicity and increases the risk of stroke and heart failure.

questions.question:
Question 18: Given below is the ECG of a patient who presented to the emergency room with sudden onset 
palpitations and breathlessness. Which of the following drugs can be used in this condition? 220 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario and the ECG findings are suggestive of paroxysmal supraventricular 
tachycardia (PSVT). Verapamil and diltiazem are used in both acute treatment and prophylaxis of 
PSVT. Their mechanism of action is by slowing SA node automaticity and AV nodal conduction velocity. 
Additionally, they also decrease cardiac contractility and reduce blood pressure. Dihydropyridines like nifedipine and amlodipine do not have any antiarrhythmic property. Drugs used for supraventricular arrhythmias are: • Adenosine • Verapamil • Diltiazem 230 
Sold by @itachibot • Digoxin Drugs used for ventricular arrhythmias are: • Lidocaine • Mexiletine Drugs used in both conditions are: • Amiodarone • Beta-blockers • Class 1A / 1C antiarrhythmics

questions.question: Question 19: Vernakalant is indicated in which of the following types of arrhythmias?
questions.explanation:
Vernakalant is a newer antiarrhythmic agent indicated in atrial fibrillation. Its mechanisms of action include: • Frequency and voltage-dependent block of the early and late components of the sodium current • The muscarinic potassium current IKACh, which is constitutively activated in atrial fibrillation is 
also blocked It is indicated for rapid termination of atrial fibrillation in patients with no or minimal structural 
heart disease.

questions.question:
Question 20: A patient presented with palpitations and light-headedness. His ECG is shown below. Which 
of the following drugs is least likely to cause this condition? 221 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and the ECG findings (rapid asynchronous complexes and an undulating 
baseline) point towards a diagnosis of torsades de pointes. Lidocaine use is unlikely to cause this 
condition. 231 
Sold by @itachibot Lidocaine belongs to class IB antiarrhythmics. It is considered to have the least arrhythmogenic 
potential among antiarrhythmics. Among the antiarrhythmics, class Ia and class III drugs prolong action potential duration and 
thus prolong QT interval. They are also prone to cause torsades de pointes.

questions.question:
Question 21: Which of the following is the drug of choice for the immediate management of a patient with 
paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia?
questions.explanation: The drug of choice for the termination of PSVT is adenosine. Drugs used for supraventricular arrhythmias are: • Adenosine • Verapamil • Diltiazem • Digoxin Drugs used for ventricular arrhythmias are: • Lidocaine • Mexiletine Drugs used in both conditions are: • Amiodarone • Beta-blockers • Class 1a / 1c antiarrhythmics

questions.question:
Question 22: A patient who was recently diagnosed with a seizure disorder presents to the casualty with 
altered mental status. His ECG shows a prolonged QTc. There is history of sudden cardiac 
deaths in his family at an early age. On further evaluation, a diagnosis of congenital long QT 
syndrome is made. Which is the most suitable pharmacological agent to treat this condition?
questions.explanation:
232 
Sold by @itachibot Beta-blockers like metoprolol are the mainstay of pharmacological therapy in both asymptomatic 
and symptomatic patients with congenital LQTS. They reduce both syncope and sudden cardiac 
death (SCD). Long QT syndrome (LQTS) is a disorder of ventricular myocardial repolarization characterized by 
a prolonged QT interval on the electrocardiogram that can lead to symptomatic ventricular 
arrhythmias and an increased risk of sudden cardiac death.

questions.question:
Question 23: An elderly patient with heart failure and atrial fibrillation is stabilized with digoxin. By what 
mechanism does it control the arrhythmia in this patient?

options.d: Decreasing atrial repolarization by blocking Na+ channels

questions.explanation:
Digoxin results in an increased vagal tone which helps in controlling the ventricular rate in atrial 
fibrillation. Increased vagal tone increases the AV nodal refractoriness due to blockade of Ca2+ channels. It 
also results in hyperpolarisation and shortening of atrial action potentials due to activation of 
ACh-mediated K+ channels in the atria.

questions.question:
Question 24: A male patient who is suffering from a psychotic disorder is on antipsychotic, antidepressant 
and antihypertensive treatment. He suddenly developed tachycardia and chest tightness. On 
evaluation he had metabolic acidosis. ECG showed widened QRS complex and prolonged QT 
interval. Which of the following drugs is responsible for this?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of torsades de pointes. Only amitriptyline causes this 
condition, among the above drugs. Torsades de pointes (French: twisting of points) is a life-threatening form of polymorphic 
ventricular tachycardia with rapid asynchronous complexes and an undulating baseline on ECG. 233 
Sold by @itachibot Hypolipidemic Drugs
